Style and such

TJS2 is a language whose style follows the lineage of the C language. Unlike BASIC and similar languages where a single statement ends with a newline, the writing style is basically "freestyle."

However, unlike JavaScript, you cannot end a statement with just a newline.

Freestyle

Characters generally called "whitespace," such as newlines, spaces, and tabs, can be placed anywhere as long as the meaning is not lost. Also, they must be inserted appropriately so that the meaning does not become ambiguous.

Example:
(1)
    function func(a,b) { a++; return a+b; }

(2)
    function func(a,b) {
        a++;
        return a+b;
    }

(3)
    function func(a,b)
    {
        a++;
        return a+b;
    }

(4)
    function
    func
    (
    a
    ,
    b
    )
    {
    a
    ++
    ;
    return
    a
    +
    b
    ;
    }

(5)
    functionfunc(a,b){a++;returna+b;}

(6)
    f unction fu nc(a,b)
    {
        a+ +;

    ret urn a+b;
    }

Among these, (1) to (4) all have the same meaning. However, (2) or (3) is recommended for readability.
(5) is written without spaces, but doing so connects the characters together, and it will not be interpreted correctly.
(6) will result in an error because spaces are inserted in places where they should not be.

Comments

Portions enclosed in /* and */ are treated as comments and are not interpreted. Comments can be nested (put inside one another).
Similarly, the portion of a line following // is also treated as a comment.


Example:
    function example(a,b,c)
    {
        return a*b/c; // Returns a*b/c
    }

    /*
        You can also write comments like this
        /* Nesting of comments is possible */
    */
